FGT5022.Name: Alter Subscriber Profile
FGT5022.Description: An adversary may alter the subscriber profile  to achieve fraud, via SBI (Service Based Interfaces) or OA&M interfaces.

Detection.description: Subscriber contacts Customer service to complain (in some limited cases)

Procedure Examples.name: AMF or SMF modifies UE context.
Procedure Examples.description: AMF/SMF can use Nudm_UECM_Update to modify UE context in the UDM. AMF or SMF can change some parameters in the UE context (which is like a subscriber profile, but valid only for a session; Clause 5.2.3.2.5 of [3]. The parameters are: PEI (Permanent Equipment Identifier), analyticsID (for NWDAF), UE capabilities, Intersystem continuity context, SMF FQDN

Procedure Examples.name: Rogue AF/NEF modifies UE’s configuration for a given external service.
Procedure Examples.description: Rogue AF/NEF via UDM can modify UE’s configuration for a given external service (e.g. pay for video for a game today). When the victim UE changes state from idle mode to connected mode, it will receive the modified services which may be inferior to the services originally provisioned. Example: NEF can use Nudm_ParameterProvision update service to update UE subscription data. Clause 5.6.2.2 of [4] & clauses 4.15.6.2, 4.15.6.3, 4.15.6.3a of [3].

Procedure Examples.name: Compromised OA&M can modify subscriber profile data in UDR
Procedure Examples.description: Compromised GUI or CLI based attack on subscriber database in UDR

Critical Assets.name: UE call/data records
Critical Assets.description: UE voice and data records accuracy

Critical Assets.name: UE static profile
Critical Assets.description: The UE static profile data

References.name: S.P. Rao, S. Holtmanns, T. Aura: “Threat modeling framework for mobile communication systems”, May 2020
S. Holtmanns, I. Oliver and Y. Miche, “Mobile Subscriber Profile Data Privacy Breach via 4G Diameter Interconnection”, 2017.
3GPP TS 23.502, “Procedures for the 5G System (5GS); Stage 2 (Release 17)”, Technical Specification, v17.4.0, March 2022. section 4.11.1.2.2
3GPP TS 29.503, “5G System; Unified Data Management Services; Stage 3”

Mitigations.name: FGM5020
Mitigations.description: Secure subscriber repositories

FGT5012.002.Name: Locate UE: Self Location Measurement
FGT5012.002.Description: An adversary may elicit location reports from UE that is bid down to less secure format or passively observes location reports from UE employing null encryption.

Detection.description: Subscriber transitions to less secure service.

Pre-Conditions.name: Permissive subscriber security profile OR system does not employ over-the-air encryption.
Pre-Conditions.description: Subscriber security profile must allow bidding down to less secure format OR system does not employ over-the-air encryption.

Pre-Conditions.name: Adversary present in the vicinity of victim UE
Pre-Conditions.description: Adversary must be present in the same area where the UE is located.

Post-Conditions.name: Subsequent attack
Post-Conditions.description: Geolocation can make electronic attack for degradation of service more effective, bidding down to defeat ID and traffic confidentiality more effective, and can expose subscriber to physical attack.

Procedure Examples.name: Self-location measurement
Procedure Examples.description: Victim UE is using a 5G system with null encryption or is bid down to a less secure protocol. UE geolocation or geolocation measurement data is passively observed or, if bid down, actively ordered through illegitimate signaling.

Critical Assets.name: UE location
Critical Assets.description: UE/Subscriber geographical location

References.name: European Union Agency for Cybersecurity (ENISA): “ENISA Threat Landscape for 5G Networks” Report, December 2020.

Mitigations.name: FGM5006
Mitigations.description: Restrictive subscriber security profile. Do not use unencrypted systems. Set subscriber security profile to prohibit bidding down to less secure service.

Mitigations.name: FGM5096
Mitigations.description: Disable location on UE device for all applications which use UE’s physical location. This is only a partial mitigation because location measurements will be sent by the UE to gNB.

Mitigations.name: M1041
Mitigations.description: Avoid systems that employ null encryption. De-register when only NULL encryption is offered

FGT1195.501.Name: SIM Credential Theft
FGT1195.501.Description: An adversary may get access to several SIM credentials either by physical access to SIM card inventory or by injecting malware on SIM vendor server.

Pre-Conditions.name: Implant malware or physical access
Pre-Conditions.description: Adversary needs to either implant malware in SIM vendor’s server or have physical access to the SIM card inventory.

Post-Conditions.name: Subscriber data leak
Post-Conditions.description: Subscriber’s sensitive signaling and user plane data are exposed to the adversary.

Procedure Examples.name: Infiltrate SIM vendor’s network.
Procedure Examples.description: An adversary may implant malware on a SIM vendor server or gain physical access to their SIM cards and thus obtain SIM credentials.

Critical Assets.name: Privacy of subscriber data
Critical Assets.description: Adversary is after getting the keys to decrypt cellular communications for those sets of SIMs whose credentials it captured.

References.name: GSMA FS.28 “Security Guidelines for Exchange of UICC Credentials”, Version 1.0, November 2020.

Gemalto article on SIM credential threat: “GEMALTO PRESENTS THE FINDINGS OF ITS INVESTIGATIONS INTO THE ALLEGED HACKING OF SIM CARD ENCRYPTION KEYS BY BRITAIN'S GOVERNMENT COMMUNICATIONS HEADQUARTERS (GCHQ) AND THE U.S. NATIONAL SECURITY AGENCY (NSA)”.
BBC article: “US and UK accused of hacking Sim card firm to steal codes“.
Securitytoday.com article: “U.S. and Britain Work Together to Pull off SIM Card Heist”.

Mitigations.name: M1017
Mitigations.description: Personnel security: Train personnel in SIM card OEMs to be wary of social engineering and other attempts of unauthorized parties to gain access to any relevant resource, and to report suspicious activities.

Mitigations.name: M1030
Mitigations.description: Physical and cyber security of IT systems, servers.

Mitigations.name: M1022
Mitigations.description: Restrict access to files exchanged between SIM vendor and MNO.

Mitigations.name: M1041
Mitigations.description: Protect the files where SIM data is stored by encryption.

Mitigations.name: FGM5024
Mitigations.description: Protect the files where SIM data is stored by integrity protection.

Detection.description: Monitor for suspicious account behavior across cloud services that share account.  Logon session logs and meta data helps determine if the session was an authorized activity.

Monitor user account authentication activity.  Monitor the activity of cloud accounts to detect abnormal or malicious behavior, such as accessing information outside of the normal function of the account or account usage at atypical hours.  Repeated attempts may be indictive of password guessing or brute force password cracking.  Password policies supporting lockout requiring administrative reset may help.

Procedure Examples.name: S0683
Procedure Examples.description: Peirates is a post-exploitation Kubernetes exploitation framework with a focus on gathering service account tokens for lateral movement and privilege escalation. The tool is written in GoLang and publicly available on GitHub

Critical Assets.name: Containerized network functions
Critical Assets.description: RAN and Core CNFs

Critical Assets.name: Cloud/virtualized container Management controllers
Critical Assets.description: Cloud, Kubernetes, or Openstack administrative controllers

References.name: ETSI NFV SEC023, Container Security Spec, section 5.4.4, Accessed 6/27/2022
Peirates
Kubernetes Used in Brute-Force Attacks Tied to Russia’s APT28

Mitigations.name: M1032
Mitigations.description: Use multi-factor authentication for cloud and virtualization OSS accounts used for VNF deployments, especially privileged accounts.

Mitigations.name: M1027
Mitigations.description: Ensure that cloud accounts, particularly privileged accounts, have complex, unique passwords across all systems on the network. Passwords and access keys should be rotated regularly. This limits the amount of time credentials can be used to access resources if a credential is compromised without your knowledge. Rotate access keys regularly.

Mitigations.name: M1026
Mitigations.description: Review privileged cloud account permission levels routinely to look for those that could allow an adversary to gain wide access.

Mitigations.name: M1018
Mitigations.description: Periodically review user accounts and remove those that are inactive or unnecessary. Limit the ability for user accounts to create additional accounts.

Mitigations.name: M1017
Mitigations.description: Applications may send push notifications to verify a login as a form of multi-factor authentication (MFA). Train users to only accept valid push notifications and to report suspicious push notifications.

FGT5016.Name: Abuse of Inter-operator Interfaces
FGT5016.Description: An adversary exploits interconnection/interworking between MNOs to obtain information about roaming user sessions or commit fraud.

Detection.description: Monitor for use of IE modification by IPX and respond when unexpected IE modifications are seen.

Pre-Conditions.name: IPX key compromise
Pre-Conditions.description: Adversary will need to compromise keys used to sign IE modifications at IPX

Pre-Conditions.name: Compromise of initiating SEPP
Pre-Conditions.description: Compromise of the initiating SEPP, typically the VPLMN SEPP, would permit an adversary to establish a protection policy that would allow IPX modification.

Procedure Examples.name: Manipulate data between two PLMNs
Procedure Examples.description: In one approach, the adversary, in a position on an IPX, could modify the messages between the vPLMN (visited PLMN) and hPLMN (home PLMN) if PRINS is used, resulting in possible information modification and/or disclosure.  Modification of an Information element (IE) could enable possible denial of service and/or information disclosure and this is addressed in [FGT5029](/techniques/FGT5029).

Procedure Examples.name: Compromise SEPP and modify signaling it sends
Procedure Examples.description: If the adversary controls a vPLMN SEPP they may modify signaling on N32 and/or generate requests to hPLMN NFs. The adversary controlled vSEPP could terminate TLS connections to hPLMN NFs and proxy requests as an adversary-in-the-middle, see [FGT1557.502](/techniques/FGT1557.502). Legitimate looking requests that could result in information disclosure or fraud may involve Value Added Service (VAS), e.g., VAS providing SEPP to the VPLMN

Critical Assets.name: SEPP
Critical Assets.description: Adversaries may need to compromise a vSEPP to perform certain activities to ensure they look legitimate.

Critical Assets.name: NFs in the vPLMN
Critical Assets.description: Adversaries may need to compromise a vPLMN NF to perform certain activities to ensure they look legitimate

Critical Assets.name: IPX signing keys
Critical Assets.description: Adversary will need to compromise keys used to sign IE modifications at IPX

References.name: S.P. Rao, S. Holtmanns, T. Aura: “Threat modeling framework for mobile communication systems”, May 2020
“Security Assurance Specification (SCAS) threats and critical assets in 3GPP network product classes,” 3rd Generation Partnership Project (3GPP), TR 33.926 ver.17.3.0, Dec. 2021, sec. G.2.4.1-G.2.4.2
G. Green, “5G Security when Roaming – Part 2,” Mpirical, Lancaster, UK, May 21, 2021
“Security architecture and procedures for 5G System,” 3GPP, TS 33.501 ver. 16.3.0, July 2020, Sec. 13.1.2,13.2
“5G System; Public Land Mobile Network (PLMN) Interconnection; Stage 3,” 3GPP, TS 29.573 ver.16.9.0, March 2022
P.Tommassen, “5G Security When Roaming,” iBasis, October 6, 2020

Mitigations.name: M1041
Mitigations.description: Block or limit cipher choices used for JWS. Use of weak JWS ciphers could allow unauthorized disclosure

Mitigations.name: M1054
Mitigations.description: Block unauthorized IE modifications by IPX. Allow only communication where authorized IpxId is not NULL

Mitigations.name: M1056
Mitigations.description: Avoid using PRINS and use direct SEPP-SEPP with HTTP/s.  Use of the SEPP to SEPP solution instead of allowing an IPX to potentially observe and manipulate information avoids the problem. A future SEPP hub solution may also mitigate this risk by providing a more scalable SEPP to SEPP solution.

FGT1199.501.Name: MNO Roaming Partners
FGT1199.501.Description: An adversary may breach or otherwise leverage a mobile network operator's (MNO's) roaming partners or their service partners to gain access to subscriber's services or obtain information about that subscriber from their home network.

Detection.description: Analysis of application logs on the HPLMN SEPP and PLMN NFs may indicate unusual control channel activity.
Analysis of network traffic from VAS, and/or IPX may indicate unexpected or unusual traffic.

Pre-Conditions.name: Compromised partner
Pre-Conditions.description: An adversary must already have compromised a trusted PLMN or one of their service providers, e.g. IPX, VAS, etc.

Pre-Conditions.name: Compromised credentials
Pre-Conditions.description: An adversary may need compromised legitimate credentials that could be used to obtain information from the MNO.

Pre-Conditions.name: Identified vulnerability
Pre-Conditions.description: An adversary may need to identify a vulnerability in an MNO network function to send specially crafted requests to obtain initial access.

Procedure Examples.name: Partner supply chain compromise
Procedure Examples.description: The service partner of the targeted MNO may themselves be targeted as part of an attack chain using that roaming partners supply chain.

Procedure Examples.name: Partner insider
Procedure Examples.description: A roaming partner, may have an adversary with a privileged position in the roaming or service partners organization and can use that position to attempt additional techniques against the targeted MNO.

Critical Assets.name: SEPP
Critical Assets.description: An adversary would want to compromise the cSEPP as it is the VPLMN end-point for the N32c channel to the HPLMN.

Critical Assets.name: VPLMN UPF
Critical Assets.description: An adversary would want to compromise the VPLMN UPF as it is used as an endpoint on the roaming network for the N9 user plane interface between UPFs.

Critical Assets.name: VAS
Critical Assets.description: An adversary would want to compromise a trusted VAS with access to the MNO’s core functions.

References.name: 5GS Roaming Guidelines Version 5.0 (non-confidential), NG.113-v5.0, GSMA, December 2021
5G; Security Architecture and Procedures for 5G System, TS 33.501 v16.10.0 Release 16, Sections 9.9, 13.1, 13.2, 3GPP, March 2022
ETSI White Paper No. 46 – MEC security: Status of standards support and future evolutions, 1st edition, ETSI, May 2021
R. Pell, S. Moschoyiannis, E. Panaousis, R. Heartfield, “Towards dynamic threat modelling in 5G core networks based on MITRE ATT&CK”,  October 2021

Mitigations.name: M1030
Mitigations.description: Minimize exposure of functions to only those partner functions that need to access.

Mitigations.name: M1018
Mitigations.description: Management of credentials used by partners to be scoped to the least privilege can minimize potential abuse. Does not mitigate misuse within allowed privileges.

Mitigations.name: M1037
Mitigations.description: Ensure communication with functions such as a SEPP is constrained to necessary addresses, ports, and protocols.

Mitigations.name: M1054
Mitigations.description: Validation of credentials properly can mitigate some AITM attacks and ensure revoked/expired credentials are not allowed.

FGT1499.503.Name: DOS a UE via gNB or NF signaling
FGT1499.503.Description: An adversary controlling a gNB or control plane or user plane Network Function (NF) may manipulate signaling to result in DOS on one or more UEs

Detection.description: Subscriber notifies provider of no or degraded service

Pre-Conditions.name: Compromise gNB or NF
Pre-Conditions.description: Adversary needs access to a fake or compromised gNB or a compromised NF.

Procedure Examples.name: DOS via gNB control
Procedure Examples.description: Adversary with a fake UE can send a De-registration request to the victim UE's gNB with the victim’s 5G-GUTI. Or, adversary with a fake gNB can send Deregistration request to the victim UE.

Procedure Examples.name: DOS via impersonating UE
Procedure Examples.description: Adversary with fake UE can try to register as the victim UE, and when the victim UE tries to RRC connect again, it will be rejected. See [2]

Procedure Examples.name: DOS via AMF control
Procedure Examples.description:
Adversary controlling Access and Mobility Management Function (AMF) can cause authentication to fail or deny SMS service by deactivating SMS for a given SUPI [1]. Control of AMF (with or without its Security Anchor Function (SEAF) functionality) can give an adversary the ability to manipulate the AKA procedure (e.g. change parameters exchanged) between the AMF and any other UE, so that (at the simplest) the UE fails authentication and cannot get services. 
Alternatively, rogue or misconfigured AMF modifies the registration accept message for legitimate subscribers to deny access to some or all services that are configured in their profile.

Procedure Examples.name: DOS via SMF control
Procedure Examples.description: Adversary controlling Session Management Function (SMF) can release an existing PDU session or not create a new one; or send a N4 Session Release request to User Plane Function (UPF) currently serving the UE.

Procedure Examples.name: DOS via UPF control
Procedure Examples.description: Adversary controlling UPF can send a report of PDU session inactivity, which results in de-activating the UE session. Or alter secondary authentication between DN AAA and SMF so it fails

Procedure Examples.name: DOS via AUSF control
Procedure Examples.description: Adversary controlling Authentication Server Function (AUSF) can produce incorrect AKA parameters or change data out of UDM.

Procedure Examples.name: DOS via UDM control
Procedure Examples.description: Adversary controlling Unified Data Management (UDM) can  fail the SUPI de-concealing operation, so that the UE key will be different and Non-Access Stratum (NAS) Security Mode Command (SMC) will fail (e.g., responding to SUCI de-concealment with an incorrect SUPI). See clause E.2.2.1 of [3].

Procedure Examples.name: DOS via ARPF control
Procedure Examples.description:
Adversary controlling Authentication Credential Repository and Processing Function (ARPF) can either (a) Alter the root key (K) or provide wrong root key for the UE; or (b) Generate wrong authentication vector (AV) during UE authentication procedure using EAP-AKA’ or 5G AKA.
Both will result in authentication failure for the UE. Section 6.1.3 of [4]

Procedure Examples.name: DOS via UDR control
Procedure Examples.description: Adversary controlling the Unified Data Repository (UDR) may give UDM incorrect security parameters, or remove UE authentication status.

Procedure Examples.name: DOS via PCF control
Procedure Examples.description: Adversary controlling Policy and Charging Function (PCF) may return a very restrictive policy for that UE.

Procedure Examples.name: DOS via NSSF and NSSAAF control
Procedure Examples.description: Adversary controlling the Network Slicing Selection Function (NSSF)  and/or the Network Slicing Selection Authentication and Authorization Function (NSSAAF) may deny UE access to a slice by mishandling NSSAI (saying it's unavailable) or altering authentication params so that authentication procedure fails.

Procedure Examples.name: DOS via CHF control
Procedure Examples.description: Adversary controlling Charging Function (CHF) may send a message to SMF to start PDU session release.

Procedure Examples.name: DOS via SMSF control
Procedure Examples.description: Adversary controlling SMS Function (SMSF) may achieve DOS only for SMS for a given UE; i.e. the device does not receive or send text messages.

Procedure Examples.name: DOS via 5G EIR control
Procedure Examples.description: Adversary controlling 5G-Equipment Identity Register (5G EIR) can mark UE as stolen.

Procedure Examples.name: DOS via Home or visited network SEPP
Procedure Examples.description: Adversary controlling home network Security Edge Protection Proxy (SEPP) or visited SEPP can alter or discard registration request/response message and/or other signaling messages to deny access for a UE.

Critical Assets.name: Network services
Critical Assets.description: Communications is denied to legitimate UEs

References.name: European Union Agency for Cybersecurity (ENISA): “ENISA Threat Landscape for 5G Networks” Report, December 2020.
Hu, X. et al: “A Systematic Analysis Method for 5G Non-Access Stratum Signalling Security”, August 2019
3rd Generation Partnership Project (3GPP) TR 33.926: “Security Assurance Specification (SCAS) threats and critical assets in 3GPP network product classes”, Technical Report, v17.3.0, December. 2021.
3rd Generation Partnership Project (3GPP) TS 33.501: “Security architecture and procedures for 5G System”, Technical Specification, v17.6.0, June 2022

Mitigations.name: M1030
Mitigations.description: Implement industry standard core and edge network function security protection

Mitigations.name: FGM5023
Mitigations.description: Periodically re-authenticate NFs in the network to assess whether they have been compromised. Remote attestation may also be employed

Detection.description: Monitor network traffic for new traffic flows, analyze socket connections and protocol used to determine abnormal behavior.
Monitor Command executions on the devices
Network elements use active and start up configuration files, monitoring configuration drifts can reveal abnormal activity
Monitor log on sessions and escalation to higher privilege activity on the devices
Monitor all user accounts accessing network devices to detect abnormal activity

Critical Assets.name: Virtual elements
Critical Assets.description: Virtual switch, Virtual Router, Virtual Firewalls, Virtual Load Balancers, SDN Controllers

3GPP TR 33.848 Security Impacts of Virtualization,
Section 5.15.2

Mitigations.name: M1041
Mitigations.description: Encrypt sensitive data flows for Control plane and User plane traffic

Mitigations.name: M1026
Mitigations.description: Manage accounts with privilege to make changes either in the device or its controller.

FGT5037.Name: Alter ML Model
FGT5037.Description: Adversary may gain unauthorized access to machine learning model or database and alters the data to disrupt service or change the behavior of network elements.

Detection.description: Access and authorization logs can reveal abnormal logging activity that precedes action taken on the system
Application logs can provide information about change, read, update, and delete(CRUD) activity.

Critical Assets.name: Configuration and session data
Critical Assets.description: Configuration and session data for RAN as well as ML applications.

Critical Assets.name: Algorithm
Critical Assets.description: ML models and algorithms itself can be a lucrative asset to acquire in addition to understanding the behavior of the models fo0r an adversary.

Mitigations.name: M1026
Mitigations.description: Strict access control to infrastructure and application supporting AI/ML operations

Mitigations.name: M1047
Mitigations.description: Monitoring of access logs, sensor data and changes proposed by algorithms and Human experts

Mitigations.name: M1018
Mitigations.description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.

Mitigations.name: M1041
Mitigations.description: Model and data should be encrypted in the system

Mitigations.name: M1009
Mitigations.description: APIs in the system should use secure access and data transport using TLS 1.3 or latest.

FGT1587.501.Name: Operator Network
FGT1587.501.Description: An adversary may create an operator network to facilitate applying techniques to a victim UE.

References.name: M.Grassi and X. Chen, “Over The Air Baseband Exploit: Gaining Remote Code Execution on 5G Smartphones”, Retrieved May 16, 2023.

Mitigations.name: M1056
Mitigations.description: The development aspect is not visible to the UE or Operator and is therefore not easily or possible to mitigate.

FGT5012.004.Name: Locate UE: Core Network Function Signaling
FGT5012.004.Description: An adversary in the core network exploits signaling protocols to obtain the location of the UE.

Pre-Conditions.name: Access to SS7 network
Pre-Conditions.description: Adversary may pretend to be an operator supporting only earlier generations.

Pre-Conditions.name: Access to operator’s network function
Pre-Conditions.description: Adversary has to gain control of one core NF.

Pre-Conditions.name: Knowledge of the UE SUPI or GPSI 5G-GUTI of target UE
Pre-Conditions.description: UE identifier required for all Core network function abuse.

Procedure Examples.name: Adversary uses SS7 interconnect (IWF) to a 5G network without protection (firewalls, etc). to obtain UE location information
Procedure Examples.description: From [3], there were recent successful attacks on SS7 whereby an attacker with access to the SS7 interconnection can find a user’s location, as well as billing data and Short Message Service (SMS) messages. In addition, the attacker can also eavesdrop on user data.

Procedure Examples.name: Adversary gains control of a core NF to get location info for a given UE: AMF case
Procedure Examples.description: The AMF gets UE location legitimately from LMF (Nlmf-loc API). Clause 8.3 of [5]. In addition, an adversary can modify AMF behavior so that it doesn't allocate a new 5G-GUTI to a given UE, so that that UE can be tracked via listening devices in the area, see [FGT5012.003](/techniques/FGT5012.003).

Procedure Examples.name: Adversary gains control of a core NF to get location info for a given UE: AF case
Procedure Examples.description: Incorrect implementation/configuration in NEF can allow a rogue application function (AF) to access UE location information using LMF services. Clause 6.1.2 of [5].

Procedure Examples.name: Adversary gains control of a core NF to get location info for a given UE: SMF case
Procedure Examples.description: The SMF can obtain a UE's location whenever the AMF sends it a PDU update request:  Nsmf_PDUSession_UpdateSMContextRequest (which contains UE location info, which can be: E-UTRA or NR cell id, location timestamp, “geographicalInformation” in hex format as in TS 23.032, only ellipsoid point with uncertainty circle.). Clause 5.2.8.2.6 of [4].

Procedure Examples.name: Adversary gains control of a core NF to get location info for a given UE: UDM case
Procedure Examples.description: The UDM can legitimately ask the AMF for the location of a UE using Namf_Location service. Clause 5.2.2.1 of [4].

Procedure Examples.name: Adversary gains control of a core NF to get location info for a given UE: UPF case
Procedure Examples.description: The UPF has access to serving cell ID for UEs that are actively sending data (RRC connected).

Procedure Examples.name: Adversary gains control of a core NF to get location info for a given UE: NEF case
Procedure Examples.description: The NEF can legitimately ask AMF Namf_EventExposure or ask GMLC directly - then GMLC gives the NEF a location report (Note: NEFs serve as location proxies to internal and external AFs in the same way GMLCs serve as proxies to external LCS clients). Clause 5.2.2.1 of [4].

Procedure Examples.name: Adversary gains control of a core NF to get location info for a given UE: NWDAF case
Procedure Examples.description: The NWDAF can get coarse UE location by subscribing to events from AMF. Clause 5.2.2.1 of [4].

Procedure Examples.name: Adversary gains control of a core NF to get location info for a given UE: GMLC case
Procedure Examples.description: The GMLC can legitimately ask the AMF for the location of a given UE using Namf_Location service. Clause 5.2.2.1 of [4].

Procedure Examples.name: Adversary gains control of a core NF to get location info for a given UE: LMF case
Procedure Examples.description: The LMF can initiate location procedure with the UE. Clauses 6.11.1, 6.11.2, 6.11.3 of [5].

Critical Assets.name: Operator network components
Critical Assets.description: NEF, AMF, SMF, UPF, NWDAF, GMLC, LMF

Critical Assets.name: UE location
Critical Assets.description: UE/Subscriber geographical location

References.name: S.P. Rao, S. Holtmanns, T. Aura: “Threat modeling framework for mobile communication systems”, May 2020
R. Pell, S. Moschoyiannis, E. Panaousis, R. Heartfield, “Towards dynamic threat modelling in 5G core networks based on MITRE ATT&CK”,  October 2021
S. Holtmanns, S. P. Rao, I. Oliver, “User location tracking attacks for LTE networks using the interworking functionality”, 2016 IFIP Networking Conference.
3GPP TS 23.502 “Procedures for the 5G System (5GS)”
3GPP TS 23.273 “5G System (5GS) Location Services (LCS)”

Mitigations.name: M1037
Mitigations.description: Filter out request messages that come from external (to the operator) sources to guard against SS7 attacks.

Mitigations.name: FGM5019
Mitigations.description: NEF authorizes 3rd party AFs for location service using policy. Nnef_Location API called by AF should be authorized properly. AF uses GPSI as UE identity.

Mitigations.name: FGM5023
Mitigations.description: Periodic authentication / authorization of NF consumer e.g. AMF by NRF will help detect rogue AMFs. Not currently in 3GPP specs, but it can be enhanced.

FGT5012.003.Name: Locate UE: 5G-GUTI reuse
FGT5012.003.Description: Adversary can track a device (get cell-level location) by listening for the same device ID being sent to the network.

Pre-Conditions.name: Adversary present in the vicinity of victim UE
Pre-Conditions.description: Adversary must be present in the same area where the UE is located.

Procedure Examples.name: Listen in for re-used 5G-GUTIs to determine UE presence in that area.
Procedure Examples.description:
Reportedly several operators do not re-allocate GUTI with every UE registration, or they do not re-allocate often enough or they use predictable pattern, as in [1], [2]. 
Exact 5G-GUTI refresh mechanism is left to implementation. Mandatory refresh of 5G-GUTI is to be done by AMF for initial registration, mobility registration update and network-initiated service request message due to paging, see clause 6.12.3 of [3].
It is not necessary for the adversary to have a UE to listen, a simpler listening device suffices.

Critical Assets.name: UE location
Critical Assets.description: Location is accurate to a cell area, since the sniffer device has to be close enough to hear the UE send its 5G GUTI

References.name: B. Hong, S. Bae, Y. Kim, “GUTI Reallocation Demystified: Cellular Location Tracking with Changing Temporary Identifier”, NDSS Symposium, 2018.

3rd Generation Partnership Project (3GPP) TR 33.926: “Security Assurance Specification (SCAS) threats and critical assets in 3GPP network product classes”, Technical Report, v17.3.0, December. 2021, clause K.2.7.1

FGT5001.Name: Network-side SMS collection
FGT5001.Description: An adversary may compromise the operator's SMS Center (SMSC) to collect SMS messages to/from the UEs.

Pre-Conditions.name: Malware developed
Pre-Conditions.description: Adversary must first develop the malware to achieve the procedures herein.

Procedure Examples.name: Malware loaded into a Linux running SMSC server
Procedure Examples.description: A data miner program may be loaded by an installation script. The script targets and saves SMS messages (the contents, the IMSI and the source and destination phone number). This is highly targeted to given IMSI numbers (e.g., proponents of movements against the Chinese gov’t). (note: Call Data Records (CDRs) were also targeted for certain IMSIs, the info therein is called metadata, i.e. time, duration, phone numbers). [1], [2].

Critical Assets.name: User data
Critical Assets.description: User data from SMS

FGT5015.Name: Device Database Manipulation
FGT5015.Description: An adversary may compromise the Equipment Identity Register (EIR) function and adds new equipment, modifies status (ok vs. stolen or prohibited) of mobile device.

Detection.description: Difficult to detect unauthorized changes. Inspect logs of what changes were made and by whom in the EIR

Procedure Examples.name: EIR database compromise
Procedure Examples.description:
Reference [1], DC-003, calls for the MNOs to employ an EIR. The rest of the attack is theoretical: an adversary may modify some of the entries in the EIR database, e.g. device status (stolen, etc.)

The AMF is the only function that checks the EIR based on PEI, upon UE registration (using the API N5g-eir_EquipmentIdentityCheck_Get).

Critical Assets.name: Integrity of device database
Critical Assets.description: Device databases should be kept from tampering.

Critical Assets.name: User equipment status integrity
Critical Assets.description: UE status should be kept accurate.

References.name: GSM Association, “GSM Association Official Document FS.31, Baseline Security Controls.”, v3.0, Sep. 2023

Mitigations.name: FGM5020
Mitigations.description: Secure EIR

Detection.description: Monitor for allowed modifications relative to the agreed upon modifications per roaming agreements and agreements with IPX.
Monitor processes which may sniff data.
Monitor commands given to NFs which may help data sniffing.

Procedure Examples.name: Non-SBI compromise
Procedure Examples.description: Adversary with access to the non-SBI interfaces (Xn, N2, N3, N4, N9) not using encryption can monitor traffic exchange and obtain UE information such as user identifiers, serving network identifiers, and location info. Non-SBI interfaces may not be encrypted for at least user plane or for control plane packets. See sections D.2.2., L.2.2., L.2.3 of [1]

Procedure Examples.name: SBI node compromise
Procedure Examples.description: The adversary with access to the SBI links, for example, with control over the 5G Service Communication Proxy (SCP) or a network infrastructure node (proxy, router, switch), may eavesdrop signaling messages if TLS encryption is not enabled. This leads to disclosure of UE authentication and authorization information, and NF IP addresses and other topology information. See [6], [7].

Procedure Examples.name: IPX node compromise
Procedure Examples.description: Adversary positioned on an IPX node can observe UE data if in the clear or easily decrypted: If a SEPP has not properly removed clear text information elements (IE) when replacing them with encrypted versions consistent with the previously negotiated protection policy or if the SEPP used a weak cipher for JWE encryption. See section G.2.4 of [1].

Procedure Examples.name: SEPP compromise
Procedure Examples.description: The adversary positioned on a SEPP, can observe information elements on the N32c interface including cipher suites used, keys, protection policies exchanged, and error messages received from the peer SEPP.  Observations on the N32f interface include cell ID and Physical Cell ID, SUPI, NF to NF signaling for a given victim UE. An adversary may utilize these observations for a number of follow-on techniques.

Critical Assets.name: UE data on roaming signaling interface
Critical Assets.description: Sensitive User signaling such as authentication data, user location for the N32 interface

Critical Assets.name: UE data on roaming user plane interface
Critical Assets.description: User data for the N9 interface

Critical Assets.name: UP, CP Data
Critical Assets.description: Signaling data, provisioning data, service discovery

Mitigations.name: M1041
Mitigations.description:
Non-SBI: Use encryption (IPSec) on these interfaces. Sections 9.2, 9.3, 9.4, 9.8, 9.9 of [2], and for N26 interfaces, see 4.3.1. of [3].

SBI: Encrypt using TLS all links between NFs and between NF and SCP if one is deployed. TLS must use certificates for both client and server, and the certificate must include the SBA node type and must be checked against what the expectation is for that other party. The TLS profile should adhere to those in TS 33.210 [9]. IPSec can be optionally used to protect TLS traffic further at a lower layer. Section 13.1.0 of [2] and also [8], [9].

Roaming: For SEPP, see sections 4.2.3.3, 4.3., 4.4. of [4], and sections 13.1 and 13.2 of [2].

Detection.description: Often these third-party applications will have logs of their own that can be collected and correlated with other data from the environment. Ensure that third-party application logs are on-boarded to the enterprise logging system and the logs are regularly reviewed. Audit software deployment logs and look for suspicious or unauthorized activity. A system not typically used to push software to clients that suddenly is used for such a task outside of a known admin function may be suspicious. Monitor account login activity on these applications to detect suspicious/abnormal usage. Perform application deployment at regular times so that irregular deployment activity stands out.

Monitor for newly executed processes that do not correlate to known good software. Analyze the process execution trees, historical activities from the third-party application (such as what types of files are usually pushed), and the resulting activities or events from the file/binary/script pushed to systems.

Procedure Examples.name: Physical sabotage/vandalism of the network infrastructure

A physical attack to 5G critical assets may disrupt, interfere and ultimately cause unavailability of the network service. Despite the existence of physical protection mechanisms (e.g., physical surveillance and surveillance cameras, security locks, security guards), physical breaches and insider threat attacks may still occur.

FGT5019.004.Name: Subscriber Profile Identifier Discovery: Intercept unencrypted SUPI
FGT5019.004.Description: An adversary may intercept unencrypted radio transmissions of a UE's SUCI to identify the IMSI/SUPI of the UE.

Detection.description:
Monitor gNB and core network logs when:


Null scheme is used for SUCI protection


Home PLMN does not configure public key for SUCI protection
Monitor Provisioning logs for changes in Home network public key configuration, PLMN ID etc.

Monitor Operations logs for:


UE makes an emergency call


In NSA mode, when 5G UE is ordered to connect to network via eNB

Pre-Conditions.name: Ability to receive SUCI over the air
Pre-Conditions.description: Adversary requires sufficient signal to capture and decode all airlink messages (with low interference and high SNR).

Pre-Conditions.name: 5G UE is directed to connect to 4G base station in NSA mode
Pre-Conditions.description: In NSA mode, 5G UE is directed to connect to eNB due to lack of 5G coverage in the area or network load situations.

Post-Conditions.name: Target association
Post-Conditions.description: When UE identity is obtained, it allows attacker to launch other attacks such as geolocation tracking, degradation of service, loss of traffic confidentiality, or physical attack.

Procedure Examples.name: Intercept IMSI/SUPI over the radio interface
Procedure Examples.description:
Adversary reads the SUCI from airlink messages using signal analyzer when it is sent in clear mode and extracts the IMSI/SUPI.

This is possible in the following scenarios:


When UE makes an emergency call and it does not have a 5G-GUTI.


If the home PLMN has configured "NULL” SUCI-protection algorithm to be used.

If the home PLMN has not provisioned the public key needed to generate a SUCI. 


UE is moved from a gNB to an eNB in NSA mode.

Critical Assets.name: UE privacy
Critical Assets.description: UE’s identity is obtained for subsequent attacks.

References.name: 3GPP TS 33.501 " Security architecture and procedures for 5G system”

Mitigations.name: M1041
Mitigations.description: Always configure home PLMN public key in the UE. Do not use NULL scheme for SUCI encryption both in network configuration and in UE configuration.

Procedure Examples.name: Free DNS loophole
Procedure Examples.description: Operators do not strictly enforce free DNS service via the standard five-tuple flow ID (src IP, dest IP, src port, dest port, protocol). Instead, they use only the destination port (or plus protocol ID), thus exposing a vulnerability. Adversary may setup fake DNS server to process the received data from victim network function/host/UE. [2]

Critical Assets.name: DNS Servers
Critical Assets.description: Whoever controls the DNS servers controls how and what end users connect to over the network, making DNS servers a type of critical infrastructure.

“Sok: Fraud in telephony networks”. In 2017 IEEE European Symposium on Security
and Privacy (EuroS&P). IEEE, p235–250
Kui Xu, Patrick Butler, Sudip Saha, Danfeng (Daphni) Yao in DNS CC Journal, “DNS for Massive-Scale Command and Control”

Mitigations.name: FGM5024
Mitigations.description: Use strong data integrity protection algorithms within 5G network such as airlink, backhaul and core network.

Mitigations.name: M1037
Mitigations.description: Filter network traffic to discard untrusted or known bad domains and resources.

Mitigations.name: M1031
Mitigations.description:
Network intrusion detection and prevention systems that use network signatures to identify traffic for specific adversary malware can be used to mitigate activity at the network level. Signatures are often for unique indicators within protocols and may be based on the specific obfuscation technique used by a particular adversary or tool and will likely be different across various malware families and versions. Adversaries will likely change tool command and control signatures over time or construct protocols in such a way to avoid detection by common defensive tools. 
Scan all external traffic header fields to detect any suspicious protocol or port number use.

FGT5032.003.Name: gNodeB Component Manipulation: rApp
FGT5032.003.Description: An adversary may compromise an rApp to affect the radio network configuration.

Detection.description: Monitor and alert on changes to rApp and cloud configuration files during runtime
Monitor rApp lifecycle management events from logs regarding onboarding, authentication/authorization of rApps. Audit logs and telemetry data for unauthorized activity.
Verify rApp image hash
Perform real-time audits and post-processing of logs. Detect which parts of the O-RAN are accessed by rApps.

Pre-Conditions.name: Adversary access to rApp
Pre-Conditions.description: Adversary has access to rApp (e.g., application package, credential)

Post-Conditions.name: Affected Network Radio Configuration
Post-Conditions.description: Adversary affects the radio network configuration, accesses configuration data, and performs other unauthorized activities

Post-Conditions.name: Network operations impacted
Post-Conditions.description: Adversary degrades network operation or in the worst case, causes network outage

Post-Conditions.name: Sensitive UE data exposed to adversary
Post-Conditions.description: UE and subscriber’s sensitive data are revealed to adversary

Procedure Examples.name: rApp access via backdoor
Procedure Examples.description: Adversary compromising external supply chain or internal CI/CD pipeline to implement backdoor into rApp

Procedure Examples.name: rApp access via stolen credentials
Procedure Examples.description: Adversary obtains rApp credentials through various means and compromises the rApp

Procedure Examples.name: rApp access via compromised 3rd party hosting infrastructure provider
Procedure Examples.description: Adversary may compromise the infrastructure the O-RAN platform is deployed on and gain access to rApp

Critical Assets.name: UE data
Critical Assets.description: UE data includes UE’s coarse location, temporary identifier and correlation of UE temporary identifier to other service-related data e.g., DNN, NSSAI etc. See clause 6.2.1 of [2].

Critical Assets.name: Sensitive network data
Critical Assets.description: Sensitive network data such as QoS policies of a slice

Critical Assets.name: RAN configuration data
Critical Assets.description: Configuration data such as configuration regarding radio resource management (RRM), QoS, and spectrum allocation

O-RAN WG2 Non-RT RIC Architecture 3.00 version

Federal Office of information Security, Study 5G RAN Risk Analysis

Mitigations.name: M1045
Mitigations.description: Verify digital signature of rApp

Mitigations.name: M1033
Mitigations.description: Use only trusted supply chain, rigorous scanning of software images. Limit Software Installations especially from 3rd party sources.

Mitigations.name: M1035
Mitigations.description: Limit access to rApp instance

Mitigations.name: M1043
Mitigations.description: Use capabilities to prevent successful rApp credential access by adversaries.

Mitigations.name: M1025
Mitigations.description: Enforce least privilege access for cloud components

FGT1557.501.Name: Radio interface
FGT1557.501.Description: An adversary may position itself on the radio interface, to support follow-on behaviors such as  [Network Sniffing](/techniques/FGT1040) or [Transmitted Data Manipulation](/techniques/FGT1565.002).

Detection.description: UE measurements of received power levels from all base stations nearby, and their identifiers Reference clause 6.24 of [3]

Pre-Conditions.name: Permissive subscriber security profile OR system employs null integrity or encryption.
Pre-Conditions.description: Subscriber security profile must allow bidding down to less secure service OR system must employ null integrity or encryption.

Post-Conditions.name: Temporary loss of subscriber data confidentiality or integrity.
Post-Conditions.description: Transient technique; works only as long as adversary-in-the-middle is able to retain connection.

Procedure Examples.name: Adversary-in-the-Middle on air interface for a given UE
Procedure Examples.description: The adversary employs a back to back gNB-UE combination. When UE security profile allows bidding down, or the UE connects to 4G due to EPS fallback, or to WiFi, an adversary acts as an adversary-in-the-middle to intercept and possibly modify communication to and from intended recipient.

Procedure Examples.name: Adversary-in-the-Middle on air interface for any UE
Procedure Examples.description: Alternatively, if the 5G system employs null integrity or encryption, subscriber data traffic can be eavesdropped or modified in transit over the air interface

Procedure Examples.name: Spoofed configuration messages from fake base station
Procedure Examples.description: Adversary uses a fake base station to broadcast spoofed configuration messages to UEs nearby. Reference [3] (appendix B) contains a taxonomy of attacks against 5G UEs, passive and active. One concerns message attacks (fake MIB/SIB – Master Information Block/System Information Block)

Critical Assets.name: Subscriber signaling
Critical Assets.description: All signaling transmitted to and from subscriber can be modified or intercepted in the clear

Critical Assets.name: UE location
Critical Assets.description: UE/subscriber geographical location can be intercepted.

Critical Assets.name: Subscriber traffic
Critical Assets.description: All data and voice transmitted to and from subscriber can be modified or intercepted in the clear

References.name: European Union Agency for Cybersecurity (ENISA): “ENISA Threat Landscape for 5G Networks” Report, section 4.4, December 2020.
Hu, X. et al: “A Systematic Analysis Method for 5G Non-Access Stratum Signalling Security”, August 2019
3rd Generation Partnership Project (3GPP) TR 33.809: “Study on  5G security enhancements against False Base Stations (FBS)”, Technical Report, v0.18.0, February 2022.

FGT1583.501.Name: False Base Station or Access Point
FGT1583.501.Description: An adversary may purchase, rent, or download software to stand up a fake base station (gNB or gNB emulator) or WiFi access point in order to pave the way to other follow-on behaviors against UEs such as adversary in the middle, denial of service, data interception or manipulation.

Detection.description: UE measurements of received power levels from all base stations nearby, and their identifiers. Clause 6.24 of [2].

References.name: European Union Agency for Cybersecurity (ENISA): “ENISA Threat Landscape for 5G Networks” Report, December 2020.
3rd Generation Partnership Project (3GPP) TR 33.809: “Study on 5G security enhancements against False Base Stations (FBS)”, Technical Report, v0.18.0, February 2022.
Cablelabs article “False Base Station or IMSI Catcher: What You Need to Know”
Open source O-RAN 5G CU/DU solution from Software Radio Systems (SRS)
Open Air Interface project source code

Mitigations.name: M1056
Mitigations.description: This technique cannot be easily mitigated with preventive controls since it is based on behaviors performed outside of the scope of the mobile network operator.

FGT5004.002.Name: Network Flow Manipulation: vSwitch
FGT5004.002.Description: An adversary may compromise a vSwitch in an SDN network to manipulate the network traffic  or cause denial of service

Detection.description: Analyze logs to detect unauthorized activity
Periodically audit SDN and Network element configuration and compare with baseline configuration to detect unauthorized changes
Periodically audit network flow tables to detect unauthorized changes to flow data

Pre-Conditions.name: Credential and Access to SDN vSwitch
Pre-Conditions.description: Privileged Access to SDN vSwitch via direct login or through SDN control plane APIs

Post-Conditions.name: Network flow compromise
Post-Conditions.description: Network flow compromise can lead to DOS or change the traffic pattern and paths.  Adversary may change the path for network sniffing or for AiTM activity.

Critical Assets.name: SDN vSwitch, operations, and security tools
Critical Assets.description: Adversary may target a particular network controller, network element, CI/CD, security, and operations tools to manipulate SDN network flows in a vSwitch

Critical Assets.name: SDN vSwitch Configuration file
Critical Assets.description: Adversary may target configuration to manipulate vSwitch and network behavior

Critical Assets.name: SDN vSwitch flow table
Critical Assets.description: Network flows are stored in Network Flow tables, usually refer to as route or switch tables that vSwitch uses to decide which packet forwarding port to use for incoming packets

References.name: ENISA, “Threat Landscape and Good Practice Guide for Software Defined Networks/5G”, Jan. 2016
Scott-Hayward, S., O'Callaghan, G., & Sezer, S. “SDN Security: A Survey”. 2013 IEEE SDN for Future. Networks and Services (SDN4FNS) (pp. 1-7)
R. Pell, S. Moschoyiannis, E. Panaousis, R. Heartfield, “Towards dynamic threat modelling in 5G core networks based on MITRE ATT&CK”, October 2021

Mitigations.name: M1022
Mitigations.description:
Restricted Permissions to add application images to SDN vSwitch for person and non-person accounts.

Restricted permissions for person and non-person accounts to prevent flow rule insertion or modification directly on the vSwitch

Mitigations.name: FGM5091
Mitigations.description: Mutual authentication between SDN controller and vSwitch can prevent unauthorized access

Mitigations.name: FGM5024
Mitigations.description: Strong integrity protection method should be employed on APIs carrying control plane traffic between Controller and network element as well as controller and vSwitch to avoid adversary in the middle threats

Mitigations.name: M1041
Mitigations.description: Strong encryption should be used on APIs carrying control plane traffic between Controller and network element as well as controller and vSwitch to avoid adversary in the middle threats

Mitigations.name: FGM5090
Mitigations.description: Logs from SDN Controller and network elements must be correlated to ensure unauthorized activity is reported. Similarly flow rules change log should be reviewed and reconciled with authorized changes.

Mitigations.name: M1053
Mitigations.description: SDN vSwitch configurations should be backed up and periodically audited to see differences between running configuration and back up configurations

Mitigations.name: M1054
Mitigations.description: Keep baseline configuration up to date to avoid loopholes due to stale configuration or configuration drift.

Mitigations.name: M1030
Mitigations.description: Physical and logical segmentation can prevent lateral movements. Segmentation techniques in the hosts and network will reduce the chances of lateral movement to the control.

FGT5012.Name: Locate UE
FGT5012.Description: An adversary may obtain the UE location using radio access or core network

Procedure Examples.name: Use radio access to locate UE
Procedure Examples.description: Adversary may use the radio access network to determine that a particular UE is in the area, or where exactly the UE is located

Procedure Examples.name: Use core network signaling to locate UE
Procedure Examples.description: Adversary may use the core network signaling to trigger the procedure of locating a particular UE via RAN

Critical Assets.name: UE location
Critical Assets.description: UE/User geographical location, coarse or fine-grained

References.name: European Union Agency for Cybersecurity (ENISA): “ENISA Threat Landscape for 5G Networks” Report, December 2020.
S.P. Rao, S. Holtmanns, T. Aura: “Threat modeling framework for mobile communication systems”, May 2020

S. Tomasin, Stefano & Centenaro, Marco & Seco-Granados, Gonzalo & Roth, Stefan & Sezgin, Aydin. (2021). Location-Privacy Leakage and Integrated Solutions for 5G Cellular Networks and Beyond. Sensors. 21. 5176. 10.3390/s21155176.

FGT5018.001.Name: Vandalism of Network Infrastructure: Cabling and junction boxes
FGT5018.001.Description: An adversary targets unprotected cables and junction boxes in order to disrupt service.

Detection.description:
Security Incident and event monitoring
Event logs recording user activities, exceptions, faults and information security events should be produced, kept and regularly reviewed. Additional considerations: development of use-case specific alert rules, integration and correlation of data at all levels (network, application), integration and correlation with service provider-level monitoring mechanisms.

Pre-Conditions.name: Unprotected cables
Pre-Conditions.description: Fibers routed between pieces of equipment without proper protection are susceptible to damage, which can critically affect network reliability. The fiber cable management system should therefore ensure that every fiber is protected from physical damage.

Pre-Conditions.name: Unprotected junction boxes
Pre-Conditions.description: Lack of protection of junction boxes / splice closures. Improper cable routing also causes increased congestion in the termination panel and the cableways, increasing the possibility of bend radius violations and long-term failure.

Post-Conditions.name: Service unavailability
Post-Conditions.description: Destruction or damage of these assets may cause an unavailability of resources.

Post-Conditions.name: Information destruction
Post-Conditions.description: Destruction or damage of these assets may cause information destruction

Procedure Examples.name: Disrupt service via physical damage
Procedure Examples.description: An adversary may damage cabling and junction boxes

Critical Assets.name: Data cables
Critical Assets.description: Data cables used in the operator network infrastructure

Critical Assets.name: Power cables
Critical Assets.description: Power cables used in the operator network infrastructure

References.name: European Union Agency for Cybersecurity (ENISA): “ENISA Threat Landscape for 5G Networks” Report, page 210, December 2020.
ISO/IEC 27011:(2016), “Information technology — Security techniques — Code of practice for Information security controls based on ISO/IEC 27002 for telecommunications organizations”

Mitigations.name: FGM5005
Mitigations.description:
Compliance with cable standards.
Raceway / conduit is one of the easiest ways to protect any cable, fiber optic included. These hollow pieces of plastic act like a protective outer shell.

Mitigations.name: FGM5005
Mitigations.description:
Secure junction boxes.
Optical fiber junction boxes / splice closures should only be accessible to maintenance personnel and maintenance vehicles. A closure should be located away from high traffic or conditions that could cause damage to the closure or injury to personnel. [2] 11.2.3 advocates for cabling security.

Mitigations.name: FGM5540
Mitigations.description: Power supply facilities in the isolated area such as mobile base stations should preferably provide an uninterruptible power supply with capacity for all loading and capable of withstanding primary power supply failures for the duration of likely outages. If that is impossible, a mechanism to provide uninterruptible power to critical equipment should be installed. Batteries may need to be augmented with a private electric generator, especially in isolated areas.

FGT1583.502.Name: Programable UE devices
FGT1583.502.Description: An adversary can purchase, rent, or download software to acquire a programmable User Equipment (UE) device, in order to pave the way to other follow-on behaviors against the Radio-Access Network (ran) such as denial of service

Procedure Examples.name: Fake UE build
Procedure Examples.description: Adversary uses Software-Defined-Radio (SDR) running OAI-5G (“OpenAirInterface”) modified software

Procedure Examples.name: Fake UE acquisition
Procedure Examples.description: In [1], it is mentioned that the adversary must “forge a malicious UE”, which is then used to replay messages form the malicious (adversary controlled) gNB to the legitimate gNB

References.name: Hu, X. et al: “A Systematic Analysis Method for 5G Non-Access Stratum Signalling Security”, August 2019
Ericsson: “Detecting false base stations in mobile networks”

Mitigations.name: UE assisted false gNB detection
Mitigations.description: Legitimate UEs send measurement reports to network periodically. Network determines anomalies in those measurement reports for presence of fake base stations. See [2].

FGT5034.Name: Radio control manipulation via rogue xApps
FGT5034.Description: Malicious xApps may gain unauthorized access to near-RT RIC and E2 nodes, in order to affect Radio Access Network (ran) behavior.

Detection.description: Monitor all xApps onboarding processes. Use host scanning tools to detect malware insertions.
Monitor logs for authentication/authorization of xApps to near-RT RIC and E2 nodes, logs for each transaction done by xApps to E2 nodes. Audit logs and telemetry data for unauthorized activities.

Perform real-time audits and post-processing of logs.
Detect which parts of the RAN is accessed by each xApp e.g. O-DU, O-CU-CP, O-CU-UP, O-RU etc.
Monitor access token usage by xApps.
Verify and refresh frequently digital signatures used for authenticating xApps by near-RT RIC and E2 nodes.
Verify xApp image hash

Pre-Conditions.name: Adversary has access to near-RT RIC during onboarding or via insider attack
Pre-Conditions.description:
Adversary installs rogue xApp in near-RT RIC via malware during onboarding and it finds out weak authentication mechanism in near-RT RIC to gain entry in the O-RAN systems.

A legitimate xApp may be cloned by adversary to launch further attacks.

Post-Conditions.name: Network operations impacted
Post-Conditions.description: Adversary degrades network operation or in the worst case causes temporary network outage.

Post-Conditions.name: Sensitive network data exposed to adversary
Post-Conditions.description: Operator’s network policies are known to the adversary.

Post-Conditions.name: Sensitive UE data exposed to adversary
Post-Conditions.description: UE and subscriber’s sensitive data is revealed to the adversary.

Procedure Examples.name: Malicious xApp gets access to near-RT RIC and E2 nodes.
Procedure Examples.description:
Adversary may exploit weakly configured authentication mechanism in near-RT RIC and E2 nodes for the xApps and may gain unauthorized access to near-RT RIC and thus affect E2 nodes.

Adversary may access E2 nodes such as O-DU, O-RU, O-CU-CP and O-CU-UP via E2 interface by using E2 related APIs. Clause 5.4.1.4 of [1], clause 7.3 of [2] and [3].

Procedure Examples.name: Rogue xApp changes behavior of ORAN system
Procedure Examples.description:
Rogue xApp may change behavior of near-RT RIC by intercepting or modifying A1 messages to/from non-RT RIC or O1 messages to/from SMO. Some examples of attacks are:

DoS attack on network and UEs by changing slice priority and QoS parameters, steal network and UE information and track UE’s location.

Procedure Examples.name: xApps stolen token/MOI
Procedure Examples.description:
When a new xApp is deployed, it is authenticated by near-RT RIC. If authentication is successful, near-RT RIC provides an ID to the xApp and it creates a Managed Object Instance (MOI) for the xApp. MOI is used by SMO to manage xApps. 

AiTM attack may be launched by adversary by monitoring and replaying a stolen token or MOI of a legitimate xApp. This may change behavior of near-RT RIC and impact RAN functions such as coverage, network slicing and QoS. Clause 9.4.1 of [2].

Critical Assets.name: Near-RT RIC function: RAN optimization
Critical Assets.description: Adversary may impact normal RAN functions.

Critical Assets.name: RAN configuration data
Critical Assets.description: Adversary may disrupt RAN operations by changing UE’s slice priority and QoS parameters which results in denying new connections or dropping existing connections.

Critical Assets.name: UE data
Critical Assets.description: UE data includes UE’s coarse location, temporary identifier and correlation of UE temporary identifier to other service related data e.g. DNN, NSSAI etc. See clause 6.2.1 of [2].

Critical Assets.name: Sensitive network data
Critical Assets.description: Adversary has read/write access to database containing sensitive network data such as QoS policies and slice priority.

References.name: O-RAN Security Threat Model 6.00 version
O-RAN WG3 Near-RT RIC Architecture 4.00 version
Ericsson white paper: “Security considerations of Open RAN”.

Mitigations.name: FGM5091
Mitigations.description: Use strong authentication and authorization for 3rd party xApps during onboarding and use strong mutual authentication between xApps and near-RT RIC and between xApp and E2 nodes.

Mitigations.name: M1043
Mitigations.description: Credential Access Protection - Use capabilities to prevent successful credential access by adversaries; including blocking forms of credential dumping.

Mitigations.name: M1030
Mitigations.description: Restrict SW paths for some network components using standard protocols such as SSL, REST/HTTPS etc.

Mitigations.name: FGM5516
Mitigations.description: Make the tokens short lived to prevent replay of token attacks (AiTM).

Mitigations.name: M1033
Mitigations.description: Use only trusted supply chain, rigorous scanning of software images. Limit Software Installations especially from 3rd party sources.

Mitigations.name: M1045
Mitigations.description: Verify digital signature of xApp

FGT5019.001.Name: Subscriber Profile Identifier Discovery: Intercept Home Network via SUCI
FGT5019.001.Description: An adversary may intercept unencrypted radio transmissions of a UE's SUCI to identify the home network of the UE.

Pre-Conditions.name: Ability to receive SUCI over the air
Pre-Conditions.description: Adversary requires sufficient signal to noise and interference ratio and must be present in the same area as the UE.

Post-Conditions.name: Target association
Post-Conditions.description: When home network is unusual (e.g., US home network in Afghanistan), allows attacker to identify UE as target of interest for geolocation, degradation of service, loss of traffic confidentiality, or physical attack.

Procedure Examples.name: Intercept home network over the radio interface
Procedure Examples.description: Receive SUCI and extract the field “home network identifier”, which is never concealed.

Critical Assets.name: UE privacy
Critical Assets.description: Home network identifier is sent unconcealed by UE over the air per standard. UE privacy such as its home network location is revealed to the adversary when UE is roaming in another country or region.

References.name: 3GPP TS 23.003: "Numbering, Addressing and Identification”, Version 17.6.0, Section 2.2B

Mitigations.name: FGM5022
Mitigations.description: When the subscriber affiliation is reflected in the home network identifier (part of subscriber identifier) and would benefit from not being sent in the clear, the subscriber's provider (home network) should be a proxy mobile network operator - whose identifier does not reveal the true affiliation of the subscriber.

FGT1498.503.Name: UE DoS to AMF
FGT1498.503.Description: An adversary controlled UE may be used to send crafted NAS messages to AMF to crash or slow down the AMF.

Detection.description:
Examine all header fields of control plane messages received in the uplink direction from UE to the core.
This can be done either by logging all messages received by the NF or by using a proxy or firewall at the core network entry point.
Test all software patches for each core NF.

Pre-Conditions.name: Compromise a UE or a purpose built UE
Pre-Conditions.description: A compromised COTS UE or a UE with open-source code running in an SDR can be used to run malicious application code. This can be used to generate the specially crafted NAS message to be sent towards AMF.

Post-Conditions.name: Network services unavailable
Post-Conditions.description: Some 5G core network services will be unavailable causing temporary network outage.

Procedure Examples.name: AMF is targeted from UE using malformed NAS message
Procedure Examples.description: Adversary controlled UE sends a crafted NAS message towards AMF with the length field increased to a very large value. If AMF does not do proper header parameters check including length check, it can cause buffer overflow in the AMF which can force AMF to go to an undefined state or crash. This will cause Denial of Service for existing and future UEs. [1,2,3]

Critical Assets.name: Core network functions
Critical Assets.description: 5G core network functions can be slowed down or crashed which causes temporary network outage for UEs and gNBs.

References.name: Github post: “[NAS] fix the security issue (ZDI-CAN-14043)”
CVE-2021-44081: “A buffer overflow vulnerability exists in the AMF of open5gs 2.1.4. When the length of MSIN in Supi exceeds 24 characters, it leads to AMF denial of service.”
CVE-2022-43677: “A crafted malformed NGAP message can crash AMF and NGAP decoder”.

Mitigations.name: FGM5511
Mitigations.description: Check for NAS message with incorrect or very large length, examine all header fields. Improve message parsing mechanism by discarding messages with improper header lengths.

Mitigations.name: FGM5512
Mitigations.description: Use high availability feature for all core network functions.

Detection.description: Monitoring ability to detect new ports, devices on the network
Monitor network traffic between hosts

Procedure Examples.name: Adding hardware to insecure open switch ports
Procedure Examples.description: Addition of unauthorized hardware in the O-RAN fronthaul infrastructure may leak data to the adversary as the fronthaul interfaces normally are not confidentiality and integrity protected. [ATT&CK T1200]

Procedure Examples.name: Privileged access to a router or switch
Procedure Examples.description: A compromised access via remote login or physical access to communication, technician interface can yield to creating span ports and tunneling traffic to network sniffer.

Critical Assets.name: RAN network elements
Critical Assets.description: RRU, DU, CU may be exposed to front haul design vulnerability or compromise.

Critical Assets.name: CP/UP Data
Critical Assets.description: Control plane and user plane data communication between DU and RRU as well as UE.

References.name: O-RAN WG11 Threat Model 6.00 version, “ORAN Threat Model”
NTIA Open RAN Security Report May 2023

Mitigations.name: M1026
Mitigations.description: Implement strong access control for all types of interfaces on originating switch and any intermediary devices on the fronthaul.

Mitigations.name: M1030
Mitigations.description: Implement network segmentation.

Mitigations.name: M1047
Mitigations.description: Perform hardware and software installation audits of all O-RAN open fronthaul components.

Mitigations.name: M1034
Mitigations.description: Limit new hardware installation

Detection.description: Use of stack canaries by the firmware author can be used to detect manipulation of stack return addresses,

Pre-Conditions.name: Lab test environment
Pre-Conditions.description: Adversary may need to deploy their own base station (and possibly core network) in a lab environment for exploit development and testing.

Procedure Examples.name: Stack Overflow
Procedure Examples.description: Researchers[1] analyzed firmware for vulnerabilities and identified stack overflow vulnerability in an XML parser inside the baseband that parses IMS messages.

References.name:
M.Grassi and X. Chen, “Over The Air Baseband Exploit: Gaining Remote
Code Execution on 5G Smartphones, Retrieved May 16, 2023

I.Karim, F.Cicala, et.al.,“ATFuzzer: Dynamic Analysis Framework of AT Interface
for Android Smartphones,” Retrieved May 16, 2023

Mitigations.name: M1001
Mitigations.description: Install security updates for known vulnerabilities.  Timely updates by the baseband vendor may make finding exploits harder.by an adversary.

FGT5031.Name: Discover TEID
FGT5031.Description: An adversary may discover a valid GTP-U TEID in order to apply additional techniques.

Detection.description: Monitor incoming packets on N6 and SGi interfaces for any unauthorized data sessions.
Inspect the payloads of all incoming packets to filter encapsulated GTP-U on internet facing interface of UPF and PGW.

Pre-Conditions.name: Obtain victim UE’s private IP address
Pre-Conditions.description: Retrieve the target UE’s private IP address using open-source search engines e.g. shodan.

Procedure Examples.name: Send large number of GTP-U packets via UPF/PGW/SGW to the target UE
Procedure Examples.description:
Adversary sends large number of encapsulated GTP-U packets with different TEIDs to a particular UE whose IP address is known to the adversary. Encapsulated GTP-U packets are sent from the internet to UPF/PGW and UPF/PGW forwards those packets to the UE via gNB/eNB. If response is received for a GTP-U packet, UE’s TEID will be known to the adversary. [1]

For example, adversary may launch further attacks such as GTP-U tunnel hijack and DoS to the target UE.

In 5G, the TEID of N3 GTP-U tunnel needs to be discovered by the adversary. In 4G, the adversary needs to discover TEID of S1-U GTP-U tunnel and S5 GTP tunnel.

Critical Assets.name: UE privacy
Critical Assets.description: UE’s sensitive data such as its private IP address and GTP-U tunnel id (TEID) are revealed to adversary.

References.name: TrendMicro publication: “A Deep Dive into the Packet Reflection Vulnerability Allowing Attackers to Plague Private 5G Networks - Security News.”

Mitigations.name: FGM5507
Mitigations.description: Randomize TEID allocations.

Mitigations.name: M1041
Mitigations.description: Use IPSec between gNB and UPF, eNB and SGW, SGW and PGW. Use strong encryption algorithms to prevent eavesdropping on subscriber payload data including their private IP addresses.

Mitigations.name: M1031
Mitigations.description: Network Intrusion Prevention.

Mitigations.name: FGM5508
Mitigations.description: Refresh TEIDs frequently to make discovery of TEID to UE IP address mapping harder.

References.name: M.Grassi & X. Chen, “Over The Air Baseband Exploit: Gaining Remote Code Execution on 5G Smartphones,” retrieved May 16, 2023

FGT5023.Name: Charging fraud via NF control
FGT5023.Description: An adversary controlling a control plane  network function may manipulate signaling or parameters to achieve charging/billing fraud where victim is UE or operator itself

Detection.description: Management system (OSS/BSS) checks uniqueness of charging ID for all new PDU sessions in non-roaming scenario and existing PDU sessions in handover and roaming scenario

Procedure Examples.name: SMF control
Procedure Examples.description:
An adversary may control the SMF and assign the same SMF Charging Identifier to a device data flow as that of an existing victim device, to cause charging errors. Clause 5.1.4 & annex A.1 of [3].

The SMF can also pause charging for a given UE (even though not warranted), clause 4.4.4 of [4].
The SMF can also misreport 5G data used by a given UE.

Procedure Examples.name: PCF control
Procedure Examples.description: An adversary with control over the PCF can change policy so that UE is allowed to consume a service it was not subscribed to - but it will still be traceable to that UE. Clause 4.3.2 of [5].

Procedure Examples.name: CHF control
Procedure Examples.description: An adversary with control over the CHF can ignore when PCF tells it that the spending limit for this subscriber has been reached or can ignore the SMS records from the SMSF (SMSF uses POST to put in data), or can ignore the 5G data the SMF reports ([3])

Procedure Examples.name: NEF control or Application Function (AF) control exploiting weak NEF
Procedure Examples.description:
Adversary on AF can attack a weak NEF. Or, the NEF can be compromised and conduct this attack without even an AF. 
An AF can ask the NEF to change the “chargeable party” Clause 4.4.8 of [6], clause 4.4.4 of [7].

This is meant to support the AF being the chargeable party, but it’s imaginable how the AF can put a different AF as chargeable: it has to send the AF identifier, UE IP address, Sponsor ID, ASP ID, etc. even AppID.

Critical Assets.name: UE call/data records accuracy
Critical Assets.description: Communications is denied

FGT5010.Name: Fraudulent AMF registration for UE in UDM
FGT5010.Description: An adversary-controlled AMF registers itself in the UDM as serving a victim UE in order to pave the way for other attacks such as fraud or UE subscription data retrieval.

Pre-Conditions.name: Faulty UDM implementation
Pre-Conditions.description: If the UDM does not store the authentication status of a UE, or the authentication status is incorrect

Post-Conditions.name: Follow on attacks by rogue AMF
Post-Conditions.description: A rogue AMF could mount other attacks on the victim UE, but the UE is not currently registered on the network. For example, the AMF can ask the LMF for the location of that UE; this may work if the UE is actually registered to this network, otherwise, it will return the last known location.

Procedure Examples.name: Adversary registers an AMF it controls as the one serving a given UE that just de-registered
Procedure Examples.description: An adversary in control of an AMF registers that AMF in UDM (via Nudm_UECM_Registration Request) as serving a given UE that de-registered. If the UDM implementation does not update the authentication status of UEs as de-registered, it will accept that AMF. The adversary-controlled AMF can then potentially perform additional hostile actions such as fraud, claiming to have provided services for the UE, or obtaining other UE information from the UDM such as subscriber data, or asking for the UE location from the LMF (Location Management Function).
