J. Hizver, “Taxonomic Modeling of Security Threats in Software Defined Networking”, Blackhat Conference, Aug. 2015
R. Pell, S. Moschoyiannis, E. Panaousis, R. Heartfield, “Towards dynamic threat modelling in 5G core networks based on MITRE ATT&CK”, October 2021

Mitigations.name: M1033
Mitigations.description: Restrict permissions to add software to SDN controller and network elements for person and non-person accounts

Mitigations.name: FGM5090
Mitigations.description: Logs from SDN controller and network elements must be correlated to ensure unauthorize activity (file transfer, patch installs, process init) is reported.

Mitigations.name: M1047
Mitigations.description: SDN controllers and network elements scanned for file changes and processes.

FGT5024.Name: IAB Denial of Service
FGT5024.Description: Adversary may jam to impact IAB or mIAB (gNB) node's communications to impact the UEs and downstream IAB node's ability to connect to network.

Detection.description: Monitor gNB logs for abnormal service outage.

Pre-Conditions.name: Adversary in the same vicinity as victim IAB node
Pre-Conditions.description: Adversary must be positioned in the same area as the victim IAB node with a wireless sniffer device and a jamming device equipped with sufficient transmit power.

Pre-Conditions.name: Adversary jams all communications of the victim IAB node
Pre-Conditions.description: Adversary impacts all communications associated to the victim IAB node i.e. both access and backhaul.

Post-Conditions.name: Network operations are impacted
Post-Conditions.description: Legitimate subscribers are not able to connect to 5G network.

Procedure Examples.name: IAB or mIAB node is jammed by adversary.
Procedure Examples.description: Adversary monitors transmissions on the IAB node backhaul and access links with a wireless sniffer device. Then it starts transmitting bogus RF signal with enough transmit power to jam the backhaul and access link communications. This will disrupt connectivity to the network of the victim IAB node, all IAB nodes that are downstream from victim IAB node, all UEs which are connected to the victim IAB node and all UEs which are connected to downstream IAB nodes.

Critical Assets.name: Network operations disrupted
Critical Assets.description: 5G RAN services are disrupted during jamming attack.

References.name: 5G Americas White Paper: “Innovations in 5G Backhaul Technologies; IAB, HFC & FIBER”, June 2020.
3GPP TS 38.401: “NG-RAN; Architecture description”.

Mitigations.name: FGM5515
Mitigations.description: Move the mIAB node to another location to avoid jamming and establish a new connection to the next hop base station.

FGT5019.002.Name: Subscriber Profile Identifier Discovery: Intercept bid-down SUPI
FGT5019.002.Description: An adversary may intercept the UE permanent identifier (SUPI) from a UE that is bid down to a less secure protocol.

Detection.description: UE transitions to less secure service

Pre-Conditions.name: Permissive user security profile
Pre-Conditions.description: User security profile must allow bidding down.

Pre-Conditions.name: Bid down operation successful
Pre-Conditions.description: Denying service to 5G and bidding down (e.g. from a fake or compromised base station) must have occurred for this 5G UE. Adversary must be present in the same area as the UE.

Post-Conditions.name: Target association
Post-Conditions.description: Allows an adversary to identify UE as target of interest for geolocation, degradation of service, loss of traffic confidentiality, or physical attack.

Procedure Examples.name: Obtain permanent UE identifier SUPI from bid-down UE
Procedure Examples.description: Adversary with fake or compromised base station sends an Identity Request NAS message to the UE to get back the SUPI. This occurs after the UE has been bid down from 5G. Clause 5.4.4 of [2]

Critical Assets.name: UE identifier
Critical Assets.description: Unique and non-transient user identity

References.name: European Union Agency for Cybersecurity (ENISA): “ENISA Threat Landscape for 5G Networks” Report, December 2020.
3GPP TS 24.301 “Non-Access-Stratum (NAS) protocol for Evolved Packet System (EPS)”; Stage 3
3GPP TS 23.003: "Numbering, Addressing and Identification”, Version 17.6.0, Section 2.2B

Mitigations.name: FGM5006
Mitigations.description: Restrictive user security profile can dictate that the UE will refuse to networks that are not 5G. The prevention of bidding-down is achieved via user security profile stored in the UE.

FGT5039.Name: Manipulate Virtual Network Function (VNF) Configuration
FGT5039.Description: Adversaries may bridge network boundaries by modifying a network device's Virtual Network Function Configuration.

Detection.description: Access Logs - Analyze logs to detect unauthorized activity to VNF and other tools used in lifecycle management and security of the VNF
Audit configuration - Periodically audit VNF configuration to detect unauthorized changes
Audit network flow - Audit network flows to VNF and other tools used in lifecycle management and security of the VNF
Image life cycle and runtime events

Pre-Conditions.name: Credential and Access
Pre-Conditions.description: Privileged Access to VNF or VNF managers via direct login or through Control Plane APIs

Post-Conditions.name: Unexpected and unusual VNF behavior
Post-Conditions.description: VNF compromise can lead to DOS or change in the traffic pattern and paths.

Procedure Examples.name: Active configuration changes
Procedure Examples.description: Active configuration changes can be made when direct access to VNF or its element managers is available

Procedure Examples.name: Stored or Coded configuration
Procedure Examples.description: Configuration as a code repository or back up configuration store can be manipulated to cause an NF to take compromised configuration upon reboot or re-instantiation

Critical Assets.name: VNF orchestrators/managers
Critical Assets.description: Adversary may target a particular network controller, network element, CI/CD, security to manipulate VNF behavior

Critical Assets.name: VNF operations tools
Critical Assets.description: Adversary may target particular operations tools to manipulate VNF behavior

Critical Assets.name: VNF security tools
Critical Assets.description: Adversary may target particular security tools to manipulate VNF behavior

Critical Assets.name: VNF Configuration file
Critical Assets.description: Adversary may target configuration in the VNF, stored in backups, or part of the code

References.name: S.P. Rao, S. Holtmanns, T. Aura: “Threat modeling framework for mobile communication systems”, May 2020

Mitigations.name: M1033
Mitigations.description: VNF Access Rights -Restricted Permissions to add images to VNFs (Network Element) for person and non-person accounts

Mitigations.name: M1047
Mitigations.description: Logs from VNFs must be corelated with other OA&M and Security monitoring tools to ensure unauthorize activity is reported. SEIM like system should be deployed to correlate events.

Mitigations.name: M1053
Mitigations.description: Configuration back ups -All VNF Configurations should be backed up and periodically audited to see differences between running configuration and back up configurations as well as comparison between configuration catalogue and running instance

FGT5004.Name: Network Flow Manipulation
FGT5004.Description: An adversary may discover Software Defined Network (SDN) flow information, which could then open opportunity for lateral movement and unauthorized changes in the network.

Detection.description: Analyze logs to detect unauthorized activity
Periodically audit SDN and Network element configuration and compare with baseline configuration to detect unauthorized changes
Periodically audit network flow tables to detect unauthorized changes to flow data

Pre-Conditions.name: Credential and Access to SDN Controller and network elements
Pre-Conditions.description: Privileged Access to SDN controller and Network elements

Post-Conditions.name: Network flow compromise
Post-Conditions.description: Network flow compromise can lead to DOS, or change the traffic pattern and paths.  Adversary may change the path for network sniffing or for MiTM activity.

Critical Assets.name: SDN Controller and Network Elements, operations, and security tools
Critical Assets.description: Adversary may target a particular network controller, network element, CI/CD, security, and operations tools to manipulate SDN network flows.

Critical Assets.name: SDN Configurations file, Network flow tables
Critical Assets.description: Adversary may target configuration or network flow data

References.name: ENISA, “Threat Landscape and Good Practice Guide for Software Defined Networks/5G”, Jan. 2016
Scott-Hayward, S., O'Callaghan, G., & Sezer, S. “SDN Security: A Survey”. 2013 IEEE SDN for Future. Networks and Services (SDN4FNS) (pp. 1-7)
R. Pell, S. Moschoyiannis, E. Panaousis, R. Heartfield, “Towards dynamic threat modelling in 5G core networks based on MITRE ATT&CK”,  October 2021

Mitigations.name: M1022
Mitigations.description:
Restricted Permissions to add images to SDN Controller and Network Elements for person and non-person accounts.

Restrict permissions for person and non-person accounts to prevent flow rule insertion or modification

Mitigations.name: FGM5091
Mitigations.description: Mutual authentication between the SDN controller and network elements.  The SDN controller and SDN application can be used to prevent unauthorized access

Mitigations.name: FGM5024
Mitigations.description: Strong integrity protection method should be employed on APIs carrying control plane traffic between Controller and network element as well as controller and SDN application to avoid adversary in the middle threats

Mitigations.name: M1041
Mitigations.description: Strong encryption should be used on APIs carrying control plane traffic between Controller and network element as well as controller and SDN application to avoid adversary in the middle threats

Mitigations.name: FGM5090
Mitigations.description: Logs from SDN Controller and network elements must be corelated to ensure unauthorize activity is reported. Similarly, flow rules change log should be reviewed and reconciled with authorized changes.

Mitigations.name: M1053
Mitigations.description: All SDN Configurations should be backed up and periodically audited to see differences between running configuration and back up configurations

Mitigations.name: M1054
Mitigations.description: Keep baseline configurations up to date to avoid loopholes due to stale configuration or configuration drift.

Mitigations.name: M1030
Mitigations.description: Physical and logical segmentation can prevent lateral movements.

FGT5021.Name: Tunnel Endpoint ID (TEID) uniqueness failure
FGT5021.Description: An adversary controlling a user-plane function (gNB or UPF) disrupts user traffic by assigning the new traffic a TEID already in use.

Detection.description: Packet inspection over the N3 interface. If two packets are seen to have the same TEID on the RAN to UPF interface, then it can be verified that they indeed belong to the same UE. It may be difficult to detect as it is per UE and per PDU session.
Charging system reports anomaly of subscriber CDRs. Periodic CDR audits can detect anomaly.

Pre-Conditions.name: Control or misconfiguration of gNB or UPF
Pre-Conditions.description: Faulty implementation at gNB or UPF ; or, control over gNB, and UPF

Post-Conditions.name: UE data disruption
Post-Conditions.description: UE user plane data gets disrupted

Post-Conditions.name: Incorrect charging
Post-Conditions.description: Incorrect subscribers' charging records are generated

Procedure Examples.name: Rogue or misconfigured gNB or UPF
Procedure Examples.description:
Rogue or wrong configuration/implementation in gNB or UPF can cause existing TEID to be assigned to a new N3 reference point or PDU session. Clause J.2.2.2 of [1]

Duplicate TEID allocation can happen during EPS to 5GS handover or roaming.

Duplicate TEID can cause traffic disruption, charging issues and eavesdropping of legitimate subscriber data by adversary. Clause 5.8.2.3 of [2], clause 4.11.1.2.2 of [3]

Critical Assets.name: UE billing data
Critical Assets.description: Billing data of legitimate UE

Critical Assets.name: UE data interruption
Critical Assets.description: UE’s reception of its data is disrupted.

References.name: 3GPP TR 33.926 “Security Assurance Specification (SCAS) threats and critical assets in 3GPP network product classes”.
3GPP TS 23.501 “System architecture for the 5G System (5GS)”.
3GPP TS 23.502, “Procedures for the 5G System (5GS); Stage 2 (Release 17)”, Technical Specification, v17.4.0, March 2022.

Mitigations.name: FGM5094
Mitigations.description: Ensure UPF and gNB/NG-eNB check for uniqueness for every new TEID they allocate locally. The newly assigned TEID must not have been in use in the past given certain amount of time (which should be set to the reasonable maximum tunnel lifetimes observed).

Mitigations.name: M1035
Mitigations.description: Limit Access to Resource Over Network

Mitigations.name: M1047
Mitigations.description: The UPF and g/eNB must keep a log of the TEIDs currently in use (which they assigned), and purge TEIDs once the tunnel is torn down. This log must be checked every time a new TEID is allocated.

FGT5003.Name: Network Function Service Discovery
FGT5003.Description: An adversary may query the Network Repository Function (NRF) to discover restricted   Network Function (NF) services to further target that NF.

Detection.description: Logging of all access requests/inquiries to NFs

Pre-Conditions.name: Access to NRF
Pre-Conditions.description: NRF is by design open to connections from other network functions. Control of another NF in the operator domain may be required.

Pre-Conditions.name: Access to SCP
Pre-Conditions.description: SCP is compromised to hijack tokens.

Post-Conditions.name: Unauthorized probing of network services
Post-Conditions.description: Information about what other services are provided by a given MNO

Procedure Examples.name: Access token abuse
Procedure Examples.description: A malicious NF can abuse access token issued by the NRF for one slice to access another shared NF in a different slice. Clause H.2.2.1 of [2]

Procedure Examples.name: Access token hijack
Procedure Examples.description: Access tokens can be hijacked by a compromised intermediate proxy such as SCP (if deployed by operator). This attack can be followed by re-direct or replay of access tokens. Clause 3.9 of [3]

Critical Assets.name: Operator network components and services
Critical Assets.description: It is possible for example to find out whether an operator provides services to a certain customer. Or whether a user is also part of a private slice e.g. DoD. There is slice isolation assurance loss with this threat.

References.name: R. Pell, S. Moschoyiannis, E. Panaousis, R. Heartfield, “Towards dynamic threat modelling in 5G core networks based on MITRE ATT&CK”, October 2021
3GPP Technical Report 33.926, “Security Assurance Specification (SCAS) threats and critical assets in 3GPP network product classes”, Release 17.
Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF) “OAuth 2.0 Security Best Current Practice”, draft-ietf-oauth-security-topics-05, June 2022.

Mitigations.name: FGM5003
Mitigations.description:
Ensure cross-layer checks at the NRF, between the certificate presented to it at the TLS connection setup stage and the identity and authorization requested presented to it at the OAuth Token request stage.
Ensure the consumer is authorized to ask about this service.

Authorization follows need-to-know rules, such as:
1. an NF cannot query for NFs in other network slices
2. an NF can only query for NFs that it needs to communicate with.

Mitigations.name: FGM5501
Mitigations.description: Inspect proxy servers such as SCP (if deployed) for any suspicious use of access tokens such as unauthorized re-direct or replay of tokens

FGT1588.501.Name: Obtain Capabilities: Radio Network Functions
FGT1588.501.Description: An adversary may obtain radio network function needed to attack target victim UEs.

Procedure Examples.name: Use of opensource SW
Procedure Examples.description: Many software defined source code are available that can be used to build a base station with radio transceiver hardware on Linux and or windows PC.  There are also opensource 5G core software available on opensource project websites.

Procedure Examples.name: Purchase of Commercial equipment
Procedure Examples.description: With the proliferation of private 5G deployments, almost anyone can now purchase software for the RAN components such as gNB, DU, CU.

Critical Assets.name: RAN Service
Critical Assets.description: Radio Communication service between UE and basestation.

Critical Assets.name: UE identity, and communication
Critical Assets.description: UE and Subscriber identity as well as communication, cellular devices and user data.

Over The Air Baseband Exploit: Gaining Remote Code Execution on 5G Smartphones
Open5GS
Over The Air Baseband Exploit: Gaining Remote Code Execution on 5G Smartphones
Open Source tools
Building a Cellphone IMSI Catcher (Stingray)
5G NR equipment suppliers

Mitigations.name: M1056
Mitigations.description: This technique cannot be easily mitigated with preventive controls since it is based on behaviors performed outside of the scope of enterprise defenses and controls.

FGT1611.501.Name: Malicious privileged container VNF Shared Resource Access
FGT1611.501.Description: An adversary may compromise a target Virtual Network Function (VNF) to gain unauthorized access to the data from the underlying resources shared with other VNFs.

Detection.description: Audit application logs (NFVO, VIM).  Configuration management databases (CMDB) and other asset management systems may help with the detection of computer systems or network devices that should not exist on a network.
Monitor container creation, container start events
Monitor process activity on node, hosts and VNFs.
Monitor volume or storage modifications, attachment or read actions.

Procedure Examples.name: S0683
Procedure Examples.description: Peirates can deploy a pod that mounts its node’s root file system, then execute a command to create a reverse shell on the node

Procedure Examples.name: S0600
Procedure Examples.description: Doki was run through a deployed container

Procedure Examples.name: G0139
Procedure Examples.description: TeamTNT has deployed different types of containers into victim environments to facilitate execution.

Critical Assets.name: VNF and VNF Data
Critical Assets.description: Adversary may identify high value 5G network functions targets for its exploits

Mitigations.name: M1047
Mitigations.description: Scan images before deployment, and block those that are not in compliance with security policies. In Kubernetes environments, the admission controller can be used to validate images after a container deployment request is authenticated but before the container is deployed.

Mitigations.name: M1035
Mitigations.description: Limit communications with the container service to local Unix sockets or remote access via SSH. Require secure port access to communicate with the APIs over TLS by disabling unauthenticated access to the Docker API, Kubernetes API Server, and container orchestration web applications.

Mitigations.name: M1030
Mitigations.description: Deny direct remote access to internal systems through the use of network proxies, gateways, and firewalls.  Segment execution environment with node and network.

Mitigations.name: M1018
Mitigations.description: Enforce the principle of least privilege by limiting container dashboard access to only the necessary users.

FGT5018.Name: Vandalism of Network Infrastructure
FGT5018.Description: An adversary aims to destroy, expose, alter, disable, steal, or gain unauthorized access to physical assets such as infrastructure, hardware, or interconnection, affecting QoS or service availability.

Detection.description: Asset tracking tools. Security Management and Detection

European Union Agency for Cybersecurity (ENISA): “ENISA Threat Landscape for 5G Networks” Report, November 2019.

Mitigations.name: FGM5005
Mitigations.description:
Communications Centers.
Communication centers should provide a full set of physical and environmental controls aimed to assure access control, monitoring, continuity of operations and protection against environmental disasters.

FGT1599.501.Name: Malicious co-tenancy  exploit of NFVI (Network Slice)
FGT1599.501.Description: Adversaries may gain unauthorized access to information via  a Virtual Network Function (VNF) shared for service designed for two different slices.

Detection.description: Audit Policy Violations - Automated user and resource policy compliance checks and instrumentation to alert on violation attempts
Audit logs - Auditing logs for security, authentication and authorization activity, host access, hosts, virtualization orchestrator and managers can reveal behavioral anomalies
Monitor systems performance
Monitor network flows

Procedure Examples.name: Create Malicious Co-Tenancy
Procedure Examples.description: A legitimate tenant 1 uses the Os-ma-nfvo interface to read the NS information of another tenant 2 sharing the NFVO. The tenant 1 may get sensitive information on the NS topology for a NS of a competitor (tenant 2).

Procedure Examples.name: Consume on-boarding resources
Procedure Examples.description: A malicious tenant on-boards unused NS/VNF just to consume on-boarding resources (e.g. fill the NS and VNF registries or software image repository) to limit the space available for other tenant.

Procedure Examples.name: Manipulate network slices of another tenant
Procedure Examples.description: A malicious tenant uses the Os-ma-nfvo interface to manage the NSs of another tenant. For example, this malicious tenant may scale down the NS of a competitor to get more resources for his own NS or scale up to increase resource cost of another tenant.

Critical Assets.name: NFVI

Critical Assets.name: VNFs
Critical Assets.description: 5G Core, RAN and NON-SBI functions, virtual resources supporting VNF

Critical Assets.description: Network slice SLA data, some information may be exposed if application functions are shared

Critical Assets.description: The application related data and sensitive parameters associated with a VNF

References.name: ETSI NFV SEC026 Isolation and trust domain specification, section 4.2.2

Mitigations.name: M1026
Mitigations.description: Least Privilege Access Control Policy - Access control policies should be granular to allow for optimal access to service requirements.

Mitigations.name: M1035
Mitigations.description: Resource Policy enforcement -Create and enforce resource policy; policy can include SLA, quotas, QOS etc.

Mitigations.name: M1030
Mitigations.description:
Security and Trust zones -Security and trust zones can help isolate resources and can be mapped to business needs.
Micro and Nano segmentation- Implementing segmentation policy at granular level, network and compute resources can prevent some co-residency threats when mapped to SLAs, Users, and Resource policies.

Physical separation- Hardware, network, and point of presence can be separated to provide additional isolation.

Mitigations.name: FGM5505
Mitigations.description: Hardware Mediated Execution Environment -Employ secure, hardware- based execution integrity as part of host/server design

Mitigations.name: M1041
Mitigations.description: Encryption can be used to protect data at rest and in transit

Mitigations.name: FGM5506
Mitigations.description: Use of Network Slice Templates -Use of templates for network slicing can enforce baseline security and isolation requirements.  These templates can be created for networks, compute and 5G slice functions deployments.
